etymologies: early 17th century (originally denoting an object used by the peoples of West Africa as an amulet or charm): from French fétiche, from Portuguese feitiço ‘charm, sorcery’ (originally an adjective meaning ‘made by art’), from Latin facticius (see factitious)

definitions: a form of sexual desire in which gratification is linked to an abnormal degree to a particular object, item of clothing, part of the body, etc.

examples.text: Victorian men developed fetishes focusing on feet, shoes, and boots

shortDefinitions: form of sexual desire in which gratification is linked to abnormal degree to particular object

definitions: an excessive and irrational devotion or commitment to a particular thing

examples.text: he had a fetish for writing more opinions each year than any other justice

shortDefinitions: excessive and irrational devotion or commitment

definitions: an inanimate object worshiped for its supposed magical powers or because it is considered to be inhabited by a spirit.
shortDefinitions: inanimate object worshipped for its supposed magical powers
